translated: Visvanatha.

original: tarhi kīdṛśaḥ san kadā prāpnotīty ata āha śraddhāvān iti /
analyzed: tarhi kīdṛśaḥ san kadā prāpnoti iti atas āha śraddhāvān iti
translated: Then, in what state and when does one attain it? To this he says 'with faith' etc.

original: śraddhā niṣkāmakarmaṇaivāntaḥkaraṇaśuddhyaiva jñānaṃ syād iti śāstrārthaṃ āstikyabuddhis tadvān eva /
analyzed: śraddhā niṣkāma karmaṇā eva antaḥkaraṇa śuddhyā eva jñānam syāt iti śāstra artham āstikya buddhiḥ tadvān eva
translated: Faith is the conviction that knowledge arises only through the purification of the internal organ by action without desire, that is the meaning of the scriptures. One who has that,

original: tatparas tadanuṣṭhānaniṣṭhas tādṛśo 'pi yadā saṃyatendriyaḥ syāt tadā parāṃ śāntim saṃsāranāśam ////
analyzed: tatparaḥ tad anuṣṭhāna niṣṭhaḥ yadā saṃyata indriyaḥ syāt tadā parām śāntim saṃsāra nāśam
translated: one who is devoted to that practice, even such a one, when the senses are controlled, then attains supreme peace, the destruction of worldly existence.

original: baladevaḥ / kīdṛśaḥ san kadā vindatīty āha śraddhāvān iti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ kīdṛśaḥ san kadā vindati iti āha śraddhāvān iti
translated: Baladeva. In what state and when does one attain it? To this he says 'with faith' etc.

original: niṣkāmena karmaṇā hṛdviśuddhau jñānaṃ syād iti /
analyzed: niṣkāmena karmaṇā hṛd viśuddhau jñānam syāt iti
translated: By action without desire, knowledge arises through the purification of the heart.

original: dṛḍhaviśvāsaḥ śraddhā tadvān /
analyzed: dṛḍha viśvāsaḥ śraddhā tadvān
translated: Firm conviction is faith, one who has that,

original: tatparas tadanuṣṭhānaniṣṭhas tādṛg api yadā saṃyatendriyas tadā parāṃ śāntim muktim ////
analyzed: tatparaḥ tad anuṣṭhāna niṣṭhaḥ tādṛś api yadā saṃyata indriyaḥ tadā parām śāntim muktim
translated: He who is intent on that, who is devoted to the practice of that, who is such, and who is also one who has his senses under control, attains the highest peace, liberation.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: ajñaś cāśraddadhānaś ca saṃśayātmā vinaśyati /
analyzed: ajñaḥ ca aśraddadhānaḥ ca saṃśaya ātmā vinaśyati
translated: The ignorant one and the faithless one, whose mind is full of doubt, is destroyed.

original: nāyaṃ loko 'sti na paro na sukhaṃ saṃśayātmanaḥ ////
analyzed: na ayam lokaḥ sti na paraḥ na sukham saṃśaya ātmanaḥ
translated: For one whose mind is full of doubt, there is neither this world nor the next nor happiness.

original: śrīdharaḥ / jñānādhikāriṇam uktvā tadviparītam anadhikāriṇam āha ajñaś ceti /
translated: Śrīdhara: Having described the one who is qualified for knowledge, he describes the one who is the opposite, who is not qualified, with The ignorant one, etc.

original: ajño gurūpadiṣṭārthānabhijñaḥ /🔽kathaṃcij jñāne jāte 'pi tatrāśraddadhānaś ca /
analyzed: ajñaḥ guru upadiṣṭa artha anabhijñaḥ  kathaṃcid jñāne jāte tatra a śraddadhānaḥ ca
translated: The ignorant one is one who is not aware of the meaning taught by the guru.🔽Even if knowledge arises somehow, he is also faithless in that.

original: jātāyām api śraddhāyāṃ mamedaṃ siddhen na veti aṃśayākrāntacittaś ca vinaśyate /
analyzed: jātāyām api śraddhāyām mama idam na vā iti aṃśaya ākrānta cittaḥ ca vinaśyate
translated: Even if faith arises, his mind is overcome by doubt, thinking Will this be accomplished for me or not? He is destroyed.

original: svārthād bhraśyati /
analyzed: sva arthāt bhraśyati
translated: He falls away from his own goal.

original: eteṣu triṣv api saṃśayātmā sarvathā naśyati /
analyzed: eteṣu triṣu api saṃśaya ātmā sarvathā naśyati
translated: One whose mind is full of doubt in all these three is completely destroyed.

original: yatas tasyāyaṃ loko nāsti dhanārjanavivāhādyasiddheḥ /
analyzed: yatas tasya ayam lokaḥ nā asti dhana arjana vivāha ādi asiddheḥ
translated: Because for him there is neither this world, due to the non-accomplishment of earning wealth, marriage, and so on.

original: na ca paraloko dharmasyāniṣpatteḥ /
analyzed: na ca para lokaḥ dharmasya aniṣpatteḥ
translated: Nor is there the next world, due to the non-fulfillment of dharma.

original: na ca sukhaṃ saṃśayenaaiva bhogasyāpy asambhavāt ////
analyzed: na ca sukham saṃśayena ā eva bhogasya api asambhavāt
translated: Nor is there happiness, because enjoyment is not possible due to doubt itself.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: atra ca saṃśayo na kartavyaḥ /
analyzed: atra ca saṃśayaḥ na kartavyaḥ
translated: And doubt should not be entertained here.

original: kasmāt / ajña iti /
analyzed: kasmāt ajñaḥ iti
translated: Why? The ignorant one, etc.

original: ajño 'nadhītaśāstratvenātmajñānaśūnyaḥ /
analyzed: ajñaḥ na adhīta śāstra tvena ātma jñāna śūnyaḥ
translated: Ignorant, because devoid of the knowledge of the Self due to not having studied the scriptures.

original: guruvedāntavākyārtha idam evaṃ na bhavaty eveti viparyayarūpā nāstikyabuddhir aśraddhā tadvān aśraddadhānaḥ /
analyzed: guru vedānta vākya arthaḥ idam evam na bhavati eva iti viparyaya rūpā nāstikya buddhiḥ aśraddhā tadvān aśraddadhānaḥ
translated: Lack of faith is the mind of disbelief in the form of the opposite idea that this is not so regarding the meaning of the Vedanta statements of the teacher. One who has that is lacking in faith.

original: idam evaṃ bhavati na veti sarvatra saṃśayākrāntacittaḥ saṃśayātmā vinaśyati svārthād bhraṣṭo bhavati /
analyzed: idam evam bhavati na vā iti sarvatra saṃśaya ākrānta cittaḥ saṃśaya ātmā vinaśyati svārthāt bhraṣṭaḥ bhavati
translated: One who has a doubting mind, whose mind is always overwhelmed with doubt as to whether this is so or not, perishes, falls away from his own goal.

original: ajñaś cāśraddadhānaś ca vinaśyatīti saṃśayātmāpekṣayā nyūnatvakathanārthaṃ cakārābhyāṃ tayoḥ prayogaḥ /
analyzed: ajñaḥ ca aśraddadhānaḥ ca vinaśyati iti saṃśaya ātma apekṣayā nyūna tva kathana artham cakārābhyām tayoḥ prayogaḥ
translated: And the use of the two words ignorant and lacking in faith is to show their inferiority in relation to one who has a doubting mind, by the two words and.

original: kutaḥ / saṃśayātmā hi sarvataḥ pāpīyān yato nāyaṃ manuṣyaloko 'sti vittārjanādyabhāvāt /
analyzed: kutas saṃśaya ātmā hi sarvatas pāpīyān yatas na ayam manuṣya lokaḥ sti vitta arjana ādi abhāvāt
translated: Why? Because one who has a doubting mind is the worst of all, since there is no human world for him due to the absence of earning wealth etc.

original: na paro lokaḥ svargamokṣādidharmajñānādyabhāvāt /
analyzed: na paraḥ lokaḥ svarga mokṣa ādi dharma jñāna ādi abhāvāt
translated: There is no other world due to the absence of the knowledge of Dharma such as heaven and liberation.

original: na sukhaṃ bhojanādikṛtaṃ saṃśayātmanaḥ sarvatra sandehākrāntacittasya /
analyzed: na sukham bhojana ādi kṛtam saṃśaya ātmanaḥ sarvatra sandeha ākrānta cittasya
translated: There is no happiness arising from eating etc. for one who has a doubting mind, whose mind is always overwhelmed with doubt in all matters.

original: ajñaś cāśraddadhānaś ca paro loko nāsti manuṣyaloko bhojanādisukhaṃ ca vartate /
analyzed: ajñaḥ ca aśraddadhānaḥ ca paraḥ lokaḥ na asti manuṣya lokaḥ bhojana ādi sukham ca vartate
translated: For one who is ignorant and lacking in faith, there is no other world, no human world, and no happiness arising from eating etc.

original: saṃśayātmā
analyzed: saṃśaya ātmā
translated: One who has a doubting mind,

original: tu tritayahīnatvena sarvataḥ pāpīyān ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: tu tritaya hīna tvena sarvatas pāpīyān iti arthaḥ
translated: He is the worst of all because he is devoid of the three, i.e., he is the most sinful of all.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: jñānādhikāriṇam uktvā tadviparītādhikāriṇam āha ajñaś ceti /
analyzed: jñāna adhikāriṇam uktvā tad viparīta adhikāriṇam āha ajñaḥ ca iti
translated: Having described the person qualified for knowledge, he describes the person who is the opposite of that, with the words, ignorant etc.

original: ajñaḥ paśvādivan mūḍhaḥ /
analyzed: ajñaḥ paśu ādi vat mūḍhaḥ
translated: Ignorant: deluded like an animal etc.

original: aśraddadhānaḥ śāstrajñānavattve 'pi nānāvādināṃ parasparavipratipattiṃ dṛṣṭvā na kvāpi viśvastaḥ /
analyzed: aśraddadhānaḥ śāstra jñānavat tve pi nānā vādinām paraspara vipratipattim dṛṣṭvā na kvāpi viśvastaḥ
translated: Lacking faith: even though possessing scriptural knowledge, not trusting anywhere, seeing the mutual disagreement of the various teachers.

original: śraddhāvattve 'pi saṃśayātmā mamaitat sidhyen na veti sandehākrāntmatiḥ /
analyzed: śraddhāvat tve saṃśaya ātmā mama etat sidhyet na vā iti sandeha ākrānt matiḥ
translated: Even though having faith, having a doubting mind: his mind is overcome with doubt, thinking Will this be accomplished for me or not?

original: teṣv api madhye saṃśayātmānaṃ viśeṣato nindati nāyam iti ////
analyzed: teṣu api madhye saṃśaya ātmānam viśeṣataḥ nindati na ayam iti
translated: Among them, he especially condemns the doubting person with the words this one etc.

original: baladevaḥ / jñānādhikāriṇaṃ tatphalaṃ cābhidhāya tadviparītaṃ tatphalaṃ cāha ajñaś ceti /
analyzed: ca abhidhāya
translated: Baladeva: Having described the person qualified for knowledge and its result, he describes the opposite of that and its result with the words ignorant etc.

original: ajñaḥ paśvādivac chāstrajñānahīnaḥ /🔽aśraddadhānaḥ śāstrajñāne saty api vivādipratipattibhir na kvāpi viśvastaḥ /
analyzed: ajñaḥ paśu ādi vat śāstra jñāna hīnaḥ  aśraddadhānaḥ śāstra jñāne sati api vivādi pratipattibhiḥ na kvāpi viśvastaḥ
translated: Ignorant: devoid of scriptural knowledge like an animal etc.🔽Lacking faith: even though possessing scriptural knowledge, not trusting anywhere due to the contradictory teachings of the disputants.

original: śraddadhānatve 'pi saṃśayātmā mamaitat siddhyen na veti sandihānamanā vinaśyati svārthād vicyavate /
analyzed: śraddadhāna tve saṃśaya ātmā mama etat siddhyet na vā iti sandihāna manāḥ vinaśyati svārthāt vicyavate
translated: Even though having faith, having a doubting mind: his mind is full of doubt, thinking Will this be accomplished for me or not? He perishes, falls away from his own goal.

original: teṣv api madhye saṃśayātmānaṃ vinindati nāyam iti /
analyzed: teṣu api madhye saṃśaya ātmānam vinindati na ayam iti
translated: Among them also, he censures the doubting one, saying, This one is not.

original: ayaṃ prākṛto lokaḥ paro 'prākṛtaḥ saṃśayātmanaḥ kiṃcid api sukhaṃ nāsti /
analyzed: ayam prākṛtaḥ lokaḥ prākṛtaḥ saṃśaya ātmanaḥ kiṃcid api sukham na asti
translated: For the doubting one, there is no happiness at all in this world or the next.

original: śāstrīyakarmajanyaṃ hi sukhaṃ /
analyzed: śāstrīya karma janyam hi sukham
translated: For happiness arises from actions prescribed by the scriptures.

original: tac ca karma viviktātmajñānapūrvakam /
analyzed: tat ca karma vivikta ātma jñāna pūrvakam
translated: And those actions are preceded by the knowledge of the pure Self.

original: tatra sandihānasya kutas tad ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: tatra sandihānasya kutas tat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: how can that [happiness] arise for one who doubts about that?

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: (Bhagavad Gita)

original: yogasaṃnyastakarmāṇaṃ jñānasaṃchinnasaṃśayam /
analyzed: yoga saṃnyasta karmāṇam jñāna saṃchinna saṃśayam
translated: For one who has dedicated actions to Yoga, whose doubts have been severed by knowledge,🔽who is self-possessed, actions do not bind, O Dhananjaya.

original: ātmavantaṃ na karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanañjaya ////
analyzed: ātmavantam na karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanañjaya
translated: (Bhagavad Gita)

original: śrīdharaḥ / adhyāyadvayoktāṃ pūrvāparabhūmikābhedena karmajñānamayīṃ dvividhāṃ brahmaniṣṭhām upasaṃharati yogeti dvābhyām /
translated: Sridhar: With the two verses beginning with Yoga, he concludes the two kinds of devotion to Brahman, which are based on action and knowledge, and which are distinguished by the stages of the previous and subsequent [verses].

original: yogena parameśvarārādhanarūpeṇa tasmin saṃnyastāni karmāṇi yena taṃ karmāṇi svaphalair na nibadhnanti /
analyzed: yogena parameśvara ārādhana rūpeṇa tasmin saṃnyastāni karmāṇi yena tam karmāṇi sva phalaiḥ na nibadhnanti
translated: For one who has dedicated actions to Yoga, which is the worship of the Supreme Lord, actions do not bind him with their fruits.

original: tataś ca jñānena ātmabodhena kartrā saṃchinnaḥ saṃsāro dehādyatimānalakṣaṇo yasya tam ātmavantam apramādinaṃ karmāṇi lokasaṅgrahārthāni
analyzed: tatas ca jñānena ātma bodhena kartrā saṃchinnaḥ saṃsāraḥ deha ādi atimāna lakṣaṇaḥ yasya tam ātmavantam apramādinam karmāṇi loka saṅgraha arthāni
translated: And then, for one who is self-possessed, who is diligent, actions for the sake of gathering the people of the world

original: svātāvikāni vā na nibadhnanti ////
analyzed: svātāvikāni vā na nibadhnanti
translated: Or they do not bind one who is in the state of liberation.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: etādṛśaysya sarvānarthamūlasya saṃśayasya nirākaraṇāyātmaniścayam upāyaṃ vadann
analyzed: sarva anartha mūlasya saṃśayasya nirākaraṇāya ātma niścayam upāyam vadan
translated: In order to remove such doubt, which is the root of all evil, he states the means of ascertaining the Self,

original: adhyāyadvayoktāṃ pūrvāparabhūmikābhedena karmajñānamayīṃ dvividhāṃ brahmaniṣṭhām
analyzed: adhyāya dvaya uktām pūrva apara bhūmikā bhedena karma jñāna mayīm dvividhām brahma niṣṭhām
translated: and concludes the two-chapter-long twofold devotion to Brahman, which consists of action and knowledge, distinguished by the difference in the stages of the previous and subsequent [chapters],

original: upasaṃharati yogeti dvābhyām /
analyzed: upasaṃharati yoga iti dvābhyām
translated: with the two [verses] beginning with yoga.

original: yogena bhagavadārādhanalakṣaṇasamatvabuddhirūpeṇa saṃnyastāni bhagavati samarpitāni karmāṇi yena /
analyzed: yogena bhagavat ārādhana lakṣaṇa samatva buddhi rūpeṇa saṃnyastāni bhagavati samarpitāni karmāṇi yena
translated: He whose actions are renounced, i.e., offered to the Lord, by means of yoga, which consists of the realization of equality in the form of devotion to the Lord.

original: yad vā paramārthadarśanalakṣaṇena yogena saṃnyastāni tyaktāni karmāṇi yena taṃ yogasaṃnyastakarmāṇam /🔽saṃśaye sati kathaṃ yogasaṃnyastakarmatvam ata āha jñānasaṃchinnasaṃśayaṃ jñānenātmaniścayalakṣaṇena cchinnaḥ saṃśayo yena tam /
analyzed: yat vā paramārtha darśana lakṣaṇena yogena saṃnyastāni tyaktāni karmāṇi yena tam yoga saṃnyasta karmāṇam  saṃśaye sati katham yoga saṃnyasta karma tvam atas āha jñāna saṃchinna saṃśayam jñānena ātma niścaya lakṣaṇena chinnaḥ saṃśayaḥ yena tam
translated: Or, he whose actions are renounced, i.e., abandoned, by means of yoga, which consists of the realization of the supreme truth.🔽How can one have one's actions renounced in yoga when there is doubt? Therefore he says, whose doubts are cut off by knowledge, i.e., by knowledge in the form of the ascertainment of the Self.

original: viṣayaparavaśatvasvarūpaprasāde sati kuto jñānotpattir ity ata āha ātmavantam apramādinaṃ sarvadā sāvadhānam /
analyzed: viṣaya para vaśa tva svarūpa prasāde sati kutas jñāna utpattiḥ iti atas āha ātmavantam apramādinam sarvadā sāvadhānam
translated: How can knowledge arise when one is subject to external objects and is of a nature to be pleased? Therefore he says, who is self-possessed, i.e., who is ever vigilant, always attentive.

original: etādṛśam apramāditvena jñānavantaṃ jñānasaṃchinnasaṃśayatvena
analyzed: etādṛśam apramādi tvena jñānavantam jñāna saṃchinna saṃśaya tvena
translated: Such a one who is endowed with knowledge by being heedful, whose doubts are cut off by knowledge,

original: yogasaṃnyastakarmāṇaṃ karmāṇi lokasaṅgrahārthāni vṛthāceṣṭārūpāṇi vā na nibadhnanti aniṣṭam iṣṭaṃ miśraṃ vā śarīraṃ nārabhante he dhanaṃjaya
analyzed: yoga saṃnyasta karmāṇam karmāṇi loka saṅgraha arthāni vṛthā ceṣṭā rūpāṇi vā na nibadhnanti aniṣṭam iṣṭam miśram vā śarīram na ārabhante he dhanaṃjaya
translated: whose actions are dedicated to yoga, whose actions are for the sake of gathering people or are like useless activity, do not bind him, O Dhananjaya, they do not produce an undesirable, desirable, or mixed body.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: naiṣkarmyaṃ tv etādṛśasya syād ity āha yogān niṣkāmakarmayogānantaram eva saṃnyastakarmāṇaṃ saṃnyāsena tyaktakarmāṇam /
analyzed: naiṣkarmyam tu etādṛśasya syāt iti āha yogāt niṣkāma karma yoga anantaram eva saṃnyasta karmāṇam saṃnyāsena tyakta karmāṇam
translated: But for one like this, there would be freedom from action; thus it is said: After yoga, after actionless Karma-yoga, one whose actions are dedicated, whose actions are renounced by renunciation.

original: tataś ca jñānābhyāsānantaraṃ chinnasaṃśayam /
analyzed: tatas ca jñāna abhyāsa anantaram chinna saṃśayam
translated: And then, after the practice of knowledge, one whose doubts are cut off.

original: ātmavantaṃ prāptapratyagātmānaṃ karmāṇi na nibadhnanti ////
analyzed: ātmavantam prāpta pratyagātmānam karmāṇi na nibadhnanti
translated: One who is self-possessed, who has attained the inner self, actions do not bind him.

original: baladevaḥ / īdṛśasya naiṣkarmyalakṣaṇā siddhiḥ syād ity āha yogeti /
translated: Baladeva. The attainment characterized by freedom from action would be for one like this; thus it is said: After yoga, etc.

original: yogena yogasthaḥ kuru karmāṇi ity atroktena saṃnyastāni jñānākāratāpannāni karmāṇi yasya tam /
analyzed: yogena yoga sthaḥ kuru karmāṇi iti atra uktena saṃnyastāni jñāna ākāra tā āpannāni karmāṇi yasya tam
translated: One whose actions are dedicated, whose actions have attained the form of knowledge, by the yoga mentioned in While established in yoga, perform actions,

original: madupadiṣṭena jñānena chinnasaṃśayo yasya tam /
analyzed: mad upadiṣṭena jñānena chinna saṃśayaḥ yasya tam
translated: one whose doubts are cut off by the knowledge taught by me,

original: ātmavantam avalokitātmānaṃ karmāṇi na nibadhnanti /
analyzed: ātmavantam avalokita ātmānam karmāṇi na nibadhnanti
translated: actions do not bind one who is self-possessed, who has seen the self.

original: teṣāṃ jñānena vigamāt ////
analyzed: teṣām jñānena vigamāt
translated: Because of their separation through knowledge.

original: BhG /🔽tasmād ajñānasaṃbhūtaṃ hṛtsthaṃ jñānāsinātmanaḥ /
analyzed: bhg  tasmāt ajñāna saṃbhūtam hṛd stham jñāna asinā ātmanaḥ
translated: BhG.

original: chittvainaṃ saṃśayaṃ yogam ātiṣṭhottiṣṭha bhārata ////
analyzed: chittvā enam saṃśayam yogam ātiṣṭha uttiṣṭha bhārata
translated: Therefore, with the sword of knowledge, cut this doubt born of ignorance and residing in the heart, and take up yoga, arise, O descendant of Bharata.

original: śrīdharaḥ / tasmād iti /🔽yasmād evaṃ tasmād ātmano 'jñānena saṃbhūtaṃ hṛdisthitam enaṃ saṃśayaṃ śokādinimittaṃ dehātmavivekakhaḍgena chittvā paramātmajñānopāyabhūtaṃ
analyzed: yasmāt evam tasmāt ātmanaḥ jñānena saṃbhūtam hṛdisthitam enam saṃśayam śoka ādi nimittam deha ātma viveka khaḍgena chittvā paramātma jñāna upāya bhūtam
translated: Sri Sridhara says: Therefore,

original: karmayogam ātiṣṭhāśraya /
analyzed: karma yogam ātiṣṭha āśraya
translated: since it is so, therefore, cut this doubt born of ignorance and residing in the heart, which is the cause of sorrow etc., with the sword of discrimination between the body and the Self, and take up the path of karma-yoga, which is the means to the knowledge of the Supreme Self.

original: tatra ca prathamaṃ prastutāya yuddhāyottiṣṭha /
analyzed: tatra ca prathamam prastutāya yuddhāya uttiṣṭha
translated: And in that, first, arise for the battle that is being presented.

original: he bhārateti kṣatriyatvena yuddhasya dharmatvaṃ darśitam ////
analyzed: he bhārata iti kṣatriya tvena yuddhasya dharma tvam darśitam
translated: O descendant of Bharata, thus the duty of battle is shown by your being a Kshatriya.

original: pumavasthādibhedena karmajñānamayī dvidhā /
analyzed: pumavasthā ādi bhedena karma jñāna mayī dvidhā
translated: The stage of life, etc. are different, and the two kinds of renunciation are based on action and knowledge.

original: niṣṭhoktā yena taṃ vande śauriṃ saṃśayasaṃchidam //🔽iti śrīdharasvāmikṛtāyāṃ bhagavadgītāṭīkāyāṃ subodhinyāṃ
analyzed: niṣṭhā uktā yena tam vande śaurim saṃśaya saṃchidam  iti śrīdhara svāmi kṛtāyām bhagavadgītā ṭīkāyām subodhinyām
translated: I bow to that Shouri, the cutter of doubts, who has taught them.

original: jñānayogo nāma caturtho 'dhyāyaḥ ////
analyzed: jñāna yogaḥ nāma caturthaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fourth chapter named The Yoga of Knowledge in the commentary called Subodhini on the Bhagavad Gita composed by Sri Sridhar Swami.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: tasmād ajñānasaṃbhūtaṃ hṛtsthaṃ jñānāsinātmanaḥ chittvainaṃ saṃśayaṃ yogam ātiṣṭhottiṣṭha bhārata ////🔽iti śrīmatparamahaṃsaparivrājakācāryaśrīviśveśvarasarasvatīpādaśiṣyaśrīmadhusūdanasarasvatīviracitāyāṃ śrīmadbhagavadgītāgūḍhārthadīpikāyām 🔽jñānayogo nāma
analyzed: tasmāt ajñāna saṃbhūtam hṛd stham jñāna asinā ātmanaḥ chittvā enam saṃśayam yogam ātiṣṭha uttiṣṭha bhārata  iti śrīmat paramahaṃsa parivrājaka ācārya śrī viśveśvara sarasvatī pāda śiṣya śrī madhusūdana sarasvatī viracitāyām śrīmat bhagavadgītā gūḍha artha dīpikāyām  jñāna yogaḥ nāma
translated: Therefore, O scion of the Bharata dynasty, stand up, and having cut off with the sword of knowledge this doubt born of ignorance and residing in the heart, resort to yoga.

original: caturtho 'dhyāyaḥ ////
analyzed: caturthaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fourth chapter named The Yoga of Knowledge in the Gītā-bhāṣya composed by Śrī Śaṅkara.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Viśvanātha:

original: upasaṃharati tasmād iti /
analyzed: upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: He concludes with tasmāt (therefore).

original: hṛtsthaṃ hṛdgataṃ saṃśayaṃ chittvā yogaṃ niṣkāmakarmayogam ātiṣṭhāśraya /
analyzed: hṛd stham hṛd gatam saṃśayam chittvā yogam niṣkāma karma yogam ātiṣṭha āśraya
translated: Having cut off the doubt residing in the heart, resort to yoga, which is action without desire for fruits.

original: uttiṣṭha yuddhaṃ kartum iti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: uttiṣṭha yuddham kartum iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is: stand up to fight.

original: ukteṣu muktyupāyeṣu jñānam atra praśasyate /
analyzed: ukteṣu mukti upāyeṣu jñānam atra praśasyate
translated: Among the means of liberation mentioned, knowledge is praised here.

original: jñānopāyaṃ tu karmaivety adhyāyārtho nirūpitaḥ //🔽iti sārārthadarśinyāṃ harṣiṇyāṃ bhaktacetasām /
analyzed: jñāna upāyam tu karma eva iti adhyāya arthaḥ nirūpitaḥ  iti sāra artha darśinyām harṣiṇyām bhakta cetasām
translated: But the purpose of the chapter is stated to be that action alone is the means of knowledge.🔽Thus, in the Gītā, this fourth chapter, which is delightful to the minds of devotees who see the essence,

original: gītāsv ayaṃ caturtho hi saṅgataḥ saṅgataḥ satām ////
analyzed: gītāsu ayam caturthaḥ hi saṅgataḥ saṅgataḥ satām
translated: is well-connected with the good.

original: baladevaḥ / tasmād iti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ tasmāt iti
translated: Baladeva: Tasmat (therefore).

original: hṛtsthaṃ hṛdgatam ātmaviṣayakaṃ saṃśayaṃ madupadiṣṭena jñānāsinā chittvā yogaṃ niṣkāmaṃ karma mayopadiṣṭam ātiṣṭha /
analyzed: hṛd stham hṛd gatam ātma viṣayakam saṃśayam mad upadiṣṭena jñāna asinā chittvā yogam niṣkāmam karma mayā upadiṣṭam ātiṣṭha
translated: Cut off, with the sword of knowledge taught by Me, the doubt that is in the heart, that is related to the Self, and take to the yoga of action without desire, which has been taught by Me.

original: tadartham uttiṣṭheti ////
analyzed: tad artham uttiṣṭha iti
translated: For that purpose, arise, etc.

original: dvyaṃśakaṃ dhānyavat karma tuṣāṃśād iva taṇḍulaḥ /
analyzed: dvi aṃśakam dhānyavat karma tuṣa aṃśāt iva taṇḍulaḥ
translated: Action is twofold like grain, like rice from the husk.

original: śreṣṭhaṃ dravyāṃśato jñānam iti turyasya nirṇayaḥ ////🔽iti śrīmadbhagavadgītopaniṣadbhāṣye caturtho 'dhyāyaḥ ////
analyzed: śreṣṭham dravya aṃśataḥ jñānam iti turyasya nirṇayaḥ  iti śrīmat bhagavadgītā upaniṣad bhāṣye caturthaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Knowledge is superior to action in terms of substance. This is the determination of the fourth.🔽Thus ends the Fourth Chapter in the Bhagavadgita.

original: caturtho 'dhyāyaḥ brahmārpaṇayogaḥ
analyzed: caturthaḥ dhyāyaḥ brahma arpaṇa yogaḥ
translated: The Fourth Chapter is named Brahmarpana-yoga (the yoga of offering to Brahman).
